body.p: The image size can be determined from the number of pixels of the image, taking the image resolution into account (if available). There are cases where this computed size is not what you need, and you want to specify the size explicitly.
For HTML, it is enough to use the image attributes directly in your document.
For an arbitrary XML, you can indicate the image width and height through a rule that matches the element (or its pseudo elements :before or :after) and sets the width and height CSS properties.

p.note: For static content as in the example above, tries to use the width and height set on the pseudo element, then the ones that are set on the parent element, but only if the static content is composed of a single image. Mixing text and images in the content property disables the width and height specification.

body.p: If you want to limit the width of the images to a maximum size, you can use the max-width property. The image will be scaled down to fit the maximum size, if it is larger.
